items.title: [bug] rrule.rrule with monthly freq is ignoring some months

milestone.title: wontfix
milestone.description: Milestone to distinguish issues and PRS that are not going to be included for whatever reason from those that just haven't been assigned a milestone.

items.body:
1. A minimal, reproducible example - a small, self-contained script that can reproduce the behavior is the best way to get your bug fixed.
```python
from datetime import datetime
from dateutil import rrule

occurrences = rrule.rrule(freq=rrule.MONTHLY, dtstart=datetime.strptime("2020-01-31", "%Y-%m-%d"))
for i in range(5):
    print(occurrences[i].isoformat())

```

Output:
```
2020-01-31T00:00:00
2020-03-31T00:00:00
2020-05-31T00:00:00
2020-07-31T00:00:00
2020-08-31T00:00:00
```

2. The platform and versions of everything involved, at a minimum please include operating system, python version and dateutil version. Instructions on getting your versions:

```bash
# Running inside docker: FROM python:3.8-slim

app@90d62953cf79:/app$ python -c 'import dateutil; print(dateutil.__version__)'
2.8.1
app@90d62953cf79:/app$ python --version
Python 3.8.5
```

3. A description of the problem - what is happening and what should happen.

When I create a rrule with freq=monthly I expect to see an occurrence at least once per month, if I use the day 31, rrule will ignore months that does no have 31 days, e.g. Feb. or Apr

This is what I would expect:

Output:
```
2020-01-31T00:00:00
2020-02-29T00:00:00
2020-03-31T00:00:00
2020-04-30T00:00:00
2020-05-31T00:00:00
```

items.title: Regression Moving from Python 2 to Python 3
items.body:
I have recently started porting a code base from python 2 to 3, including `dateutil`. I've noticed there is a regression in behavior for some dates that are not perfectly formatted. In the examples below, it tries to parse `'Sep. 19,2013'`:

### Python 2 Behavior
```
import dateutil.parser
dateutil.parser.parse('Sep. 19,2013')
> datetime.datetime(2013, 9, 19, 0, 0)
````
### Python 3 Behavior
```
import dateutil.parser
dateutil.parser.parse('Sep. 19,2013')
> datetime.datetime(2020, 9, 19, 0, 0)
````

The Python 2 behavior appears to be more correct in this case. Is this type of imperfect date formatting supposed to be supported by dateutil? Any way to get the older behavior working in Python 3? We rely on some of this cleanup.

items.title: Yearly events are interpreted as monthly events when BYMONTHDAY is used
items.body:
If not only "FREQ=YEARLY" is set for yearly events, but also the parameter "BYMONTHDAY=..." - like the Windows 10 calendar app is doing - then `rrulestr` interprets them wrongly as monthly events.

Correct with `FREQ=YEARLY`only, one event per year:
```
>>> from dateutil.rrule import rrulestr
>>> list(rrulestr("""DTSTART;VALUE=DATE:20200716\nRRULE:FREQ=YEARLY;COUNT=3\n"""))
[datetime.datetime(2020, 7, 16, 0, 0), datetime.datetime(2021, 7, 16, 0, 0), datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 16, 0, 0)]
```

Correct with `FREQ=YEARLY;WKST=MO;INTERVAL=1`, one event per year:
```
>>> from dateutil.rrule import rrulestr
>>> list(rrulestr("""DTSTART;VALUE=DATE:20200716\nRRULE:FREQ=YEARLY;WKST=MO;INTERVAL=1;COUNT=3\n"""))
[datetime.datetime(2020, 7, 16, 0, 0), datetime.datetime(2021, 7, 16, 0, 0), datetime.datetime(2022, 7, 16, 0, 0)]
```

Wrong with `FREQ=YEARLY;WKST=MO;INTERVAL=1;BYMONTHDAY=16`, one event per month:
```
>>> from dateutil.rrule import rrulestr
>>> list(rrulestr("""DTSTART;VALUE=DATE:20200716\nRRULE:FREQ=YEARLY;WKST=MO;INTERVAL=1;BYMONTHDAY=16;COUNT=3\n"""))
[datetime.datetime(2020, 7, 16, 0, 0), datetime.datetime(2020, 8, 16, 0, 0), datetime.datetime(2020, 9, 16, 0, 0)]
```

items.title: Parser fails to parse YYYY:MM:DD
items.body:
Hi, for some reason the parser cannot handle colon (":") symbol and returns the current time. When the colon is replaced with a hyphen ("-"), the parser works correctly.

```
>>> from dateutil.parser import parse
>>> parse('2011:01:08 23:44:36')

datetime.datetime(2020, 6, 27, 23, 44, 36)

>>> parse('2011-01-08 23:44:36')

datetime.datetime(2011, 1, 8, 23, 44, 36)
```

items.title: America/Nuuk timezone not recognized
items.body:
We were in the process of updating testing dependencies for Arrow (https://github.com/crsmithdev/arrow) and our formatting tests, which run on the entire TZ database, are failing due to dateutil not recognizing the timezone "America/Nuuk". Instead of returning an appropriate `tzfile`, dateutil seems to return `None` instead. This seems to be a symptom of updating `pytz` to version `2020.1`. Below is a snippet of code showing this issue in action:

```shell
venv ❯ python3
Python 3.7.7 (default, Mar 10 2020, 15:43:33)
[Clang 11.0.0 (clang-1100.0.33.17)] on darwin
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> from dateutil import tz
>>> tz.gettz("America/Nuuk")
>>> tz.gettz("America/New York")
tzfile('/usr/share/zoneinfo/America/New_York')
```

items.title: Parser raises TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) when handling calendar.IllegalMonthError
items.body:
The string `æ\x9få\x9b\x9b, 22 å\n«æ\x9c 2013 11:27:40 +0800` is interpreted to have month number 22 - which is rightly rejected by `calendar`. There appears to be a problem with how this exception is handled by `dateutil` however as instead of the expected `ValueError` a `TypeError` is raised instead:

**How to reproduce**

```
>>> parser.parse("æ\x9få\x9b\x9b, 22 å\n«æ\x9c 2013 11:27:40 +0800", fuzzy=True)
```

**Expected**

Some sort of `ValueError`

**Actual**

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<>/venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/dateutil/parser/_parser.py", line 655, in parse
    ret = self._build_naive(res, default)
  File "<>/venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/dateutil/parser/_parser.py", line 1238, in _build_naive
    if cday > monthrange(cyear, cmonth)[1]:
  File "/usr/lib/python3.7/calendar.py", line 124, in monthrange
    raise IllegalMonthError(month)
calendar.IllegalMonthError: bad month number 22; must be 1-12

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "<>/venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/dateutil/parser/_parser.py", line 1374, in parse
    return DEFAULTPARSER.parse(timestr, **kwargs)
  File "<>/venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/dateutil/parser/_parser.py", line 657, in parse
    six.raise_from(ParserError(e.args[0] + ": %s", timestr), e)
TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for +: 'int' and 'str'
```

**Environment**
Platform: Ubuntu 18.04.4/Debian 10 (docker container)
Python version: 3.7.5
dateutil version: 2.8.1

items.title: Why does the source code license say "all rights reserved" when you don't reserve all rights?
items.body:
In the license file it reads;
```
All rights reserved.

Redistribution and use in source and binary forms, with or without
modification, are permitted provided that the following conditions are met:
```
At first, all rights are reserved, then you grant usage rights, modification rights, and distribution rights. This is confusing. In addition, "All rights reserved" has no legal meaning and is a deprecated term which likely should be removed to reduce licensing ambiguity.

items.title: Incorrect timedelta when substracting DST and non DST

milestone.title: wontfix
milestone.description: Milestone to distinguish issues and PRS that are not going to be included for whatever reason from those that just haven't been assigned a milestone.

items.body:
Hi,

I am facing the following issue:

dateutil: 2.8.1
Python: Python 3.7.3

```python
>>> import dateutil; print(dateutil.__version__)
2.8.1
>>> import datetime
>>> from dateutil.tz import gettz
>>> time_a = datetime.datetime(2020,3,7,19,40, tzinfo=gettz("America/Toronto"))
>>> time_b = datetime.datetime(2020,3,8,7,40, tzinfo=gettz("America/Toronto"))
>>> time_a.isoformat()
'2020-03-07T19:40:00-05:00'
>>> time_b.isoformat()
'2020-03-08T07:40:00-04:00'
>>> from dateutil.relativedelta import relativedelta
>>> relativedelta(time_b, time_a)
relativedelta(hours=+12)
```

This should be +11 as there was a change in daylight savings time.

items.title: March 3rd 1am US/Eastern equals one hour later when converted to UTC
items.body:
Minimal repro:
```
>>> from datetime import datetime, timedelta
>>> from dateutil.tz import tz
>>> ONE_HOUR = timedelta(hours=1)
>>> utc = tz.tzutc()
>>> d = datetime(2020, 3, 8, 1, 1, tzinfo=tz.gettz("US/Eastern"))
>>> d == (d + ONE_HOUR)
False
>>> d.astimezone(utc) == (d + ONE_HOUR).astimezone(utc)
True
```
I thought that the last equality check above should always be False, for all timezone-aware datetimes, no matter what timezones the datetime is converted to.

I checked that I see the correct behavior (at least what I expected) when I set d to an hour earlier (if d is March 3rd, 2020 at 00:01 then the final check is False). I did not check other timezones or dates.

I'm guessing that this is probably related to daylight savings time somehow, as DST in 2020 starts on March 3rd at 2am.

Versions:
```
> python --version
Python 3.6.3
> python -c 'import dateutil; print(dateutil.__version__)'
2.8.1
```

Note that these following equalities are also true. 
```
>>> d == d.astimezone(utc)
True
>>> (d + ONE_HOUR) == d.astimezone(utc)
True
>>> d == (d + ONE_HOUR)
False
```
So both `d` and `d + ONE_HOUR` are both equal to `d.astimezone(utc)` but somehow still not equal to each other.

items.title: parser.parse documentation doesn't mention ParserError
items.body:
The current documentation for `parser.parse` says that `ValueError`, rather than `ParserError` is raised. The `ParserError` exception itself is also not documented.

I will fix both of these in a forthcoming PR.

items.title: ParserError custom __repr__ is not reached
items.body:
There is an indentation error in [the definition for `__str__`/`__repr__` in `dateutil.parser.ParserError`](https://github.com/dateutil/dateutil/blob/f6c6d5cb97ce460c9510846bf14e945b2b16ead0/dateutil/parser/_parser.py#L1603), which means that `__repr__` is never even defined for the class:

```
>>> from dateutil.parser import ParserError
>>> ParserError("Hi")
dateutil.parser._parser.ParserError('Hi')
```

I think the definition of the repr is also a bit problematic, in that even if you fix the indentation issue, it would return `ParserError(Hi)` instead of `ParserError('Hi')` in the above situation. I will make a PR shortly.

items.title: parser raises `TypeError` in wrapper logic
items.body:
Apparently sometimes the parser catches a type of `ValueError` *other* than the ones we raise - specifically `IllegalMonthError`, which takes as an argument something other than a string. Minimal reproducer:

```python
>>> from dateutil import parser
>>> parser.parse("0-100")
>>> dateutil.parser.parse("0-100")
```

This raises the following error:
<details>

```
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
IllegalMonthError                         Traceback (most recent call last)
/usr/lib/python3.7/site-packages/dateutil/parser/_parser.py in parse(self, timestr, default, ignoretz, tzinfos, **kwargs)
    654         try:
--> 655             ret = self._build_naive(res, default)
    656         except ValueError as e:

/usr/lib/python3.7/site-packages/dateutil/parser/_parser.py in _build_naive(self, res, default)
   1237
-> 1238             if cday > monthrange(cyear, cmonth)[1]:
   1239                 repl['day'] = monthrange(cyear, cmonth)[1]

/usr/lib/python3.7/calendar.py in monthrange(year, month)
    123     if not 1 <= month <= 12:
--> 124         raise IllegalMonthError(month)
    125     day1 = weekday(year, month, 1)

IllegalMonthError: bad month number 0; must be 1-12

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

TypeError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-3-f7db2d9dc78c> in <module>
----> 1 dateutil.parser.parse("0-100")

/usr/lib/python3.7/site-packages/dateutil/parser/_parser.py in parse(timestr, parserinfo, **kwargs)
   1372         return parser(parserinfo).parse(timestr, **kwargs)
   1373     else:
-> 1374         return DEFAULTPARSER.parse(timestr, **kwargs)
   1375
   1376

/usr/lib/python3.7/site-packages/dateutil/parser/_parser.py in parse(self, timestr, default, ignoretz, tzinfos, **kwargs)
    655             ret = self._build_naive(res, default)
    656         except ValueError as e:
--> 657             six.raise_from(ParserError(e.args[0] + ": %s", timestr), e)
    658
    659         if not ignoretz:

TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for +: 'int' and 'str'
```
</details>

The core of the issue is [this line](https://github.com/dateutil/dateutil/blob/fc9b1625ebc729f01e449879b6b140abd12ae621/dateutil/parser/_parser.py#L657):

```python
        try:
            ret = self._build_naive(res, default)
        except ValueError as e:
            six.raise_from(ParserError(e.args[0] + ": %s", timestr), e)
```

Since `e.args[0]` is apparently occasionally an integer.

I guess we can solve this this way:

```python
except ValueError as e:
    six.raise_from(ParseError(str(e) + ": %s", timestr), e)
```

This will need a regression test. This is apparently the cause of matplotlib/matplotlib#15726.

items.title: Odd parsing of date time with timezone and offset

milestone.title: wontfix
milestone.description: Milestone to distinguish issues and PRS that are not going to be included for whatever reason from those that just haven't been assigned a milestone.

items.body:
Often timezone offset is specified as UTC or GMT plus-minus some number, e.g. GMT+02:00 for Central European time. UTC time can be calculated by subtracting the offset from the local time. The same way the local time is calculated by adding the offset to UTC time.

For example that's how this is done in JavaScript:
```
> console.log(new Date('2019-10-15T15:00:12.220Z'));
Tue Oct 15 2019 17:00:12 GMT+0200 (Central European Summer Time)
```

But dateutil interprets timezone offset completely opposite:
```
> dateutil.parser.parse('Tue Oct 15 2019 17:00:12 GMT+0200').astimezone(timezone.utc)
datetime.datetime(2019, 10, 15, 19, 0, 12, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)
```

According to code comments this behaviour is as designed (https://github.com/dateutil/dateutil/blame/master/dateutil/parser/_parser.py#L803). But shouldn't it be changed to conform to interpretation the has become a standard?

So here is an interesting data integrity problem for the Python community. Running:

pip install python-dateutil

Actually installs:

python_dateutil... .whl
Which when unzipped reveals:

dateutil
python_dateutil....dist-info
Is it possible to get this cleaned up and consistent given the #5 most used package positition?

items.title: Should dateutil include common TZ abbreviations?
items.body:
I am using dateutil to parse dates included in RSS feeds which are mostly RFC 822 dates. These dates often make use of timezone abbreviations like `EDT`, `PST`...

Dateutil does not know these abbreviations so it defaults to returning a naive datetime and warns with a `UnknownTimezoneWarning`.

I know that I can pass a `tzinfos` dict to map these abbreviations to a known timezone, but I'm not sure that application code is the best place to store these mappings.

Should dateutil include common timezone abbreviations?

items.title: Move all simple constants from setup.py into setup.cfg

milestone.title: Master
milestone.description: This is a general milestone for things that are useful between releases, like build and test improvements.

items.body:
Nearly all the options in [our `setup.py`](https://setuptools.readthedocs.io/en/latest/setuptools.html#configuring-setup-using-setup-cfg-files) can be moved over to `setup.cfg`.

The only things that need to stay are:

1. `use_scm_version` (I believe there is no declarative option for this)
2. The README configuration, which involves modifying the README
3. `cmdclass`, which I think has no declarative alternative

The trickiest part will be converting the `find_packages` option over, but that is covered in the setuptools documentation I linked to, you specify it as `packages = find:`, and then pass the options in `[options.packages.find]`.

For bonus points, we may be able to switch over the `README` thing by switching `README` over to using `.. code-block :: python3` directly, and then doing a search-and-replace as part of the [docs build](https://github.com/dateutil/dateutil/blob/master/docs/conf.py) instead. This will be a bit tricky, though, because `README.rst` is included in the docs with an RST include, which means we would have to create a temporary file that would be included. For now, this ticket can be closed if we do everything *except* that.

items.title: Add a "build" job in tox

milestone.title: Master
milestone.description: This is a general milestone for things that are useful between releases, like build and test improvements.

items.body:
I would like to start phasing out my ad-hoc [release.py](https://github.com/dateutil/dateutil/blob/master/release.py) file in favor of a `tox` environment, which will allow me to declare explicit dependencies and will make things all-around easier.

For the moment, we can use [virtualenv's "publish" function](https://github.com/pypa/virtualenv/blob/master/tox.ini#L124) as a template that wraps the existing `release.py` script.

It should declare a dependency on `click >= 7.0`. If #869 is already done, you also need to declare a dependency on `pep517 >= 0.5.0`.

I would like to test this in some way as well, so please add a job in Travis (or Azure pipelines if #868 has already been merged) that runs `tox -e build` and ensures that it populates the specified directory with a `.tar.gz` file and a `.whl` file.

To Do:
- [x] Add `build` environment
- [x] Add test for `build` environment

items.title: Use pep517.build in release.py

milestone.title: Master
milestone.description: This is a general milestone for things that are useful between releases, like build and test improvements.

items.body:
We are now fully compliant with PEP 517 and PEP 518 (see [this three article series by @gaborbernat for more information](https://www.bernat.tech/pep-517-and-python-packaging/)), and so I'd like to start building our release artifacts using a PEP 517 build front-end.

At the moment, I think the best one is the [`pep517` library](https://pypi.org/project/pep517/). The easiest thing to do is to change [this part of `release.py`](https://github.com/dateutil/dateutil/blob/master/release.py#L28) over to a single call to `pep517.build`:

```python
subprocess.check_call(['python', '-m', 'pep517.build', '--binary', '--source', '.'])
```

We will also want to specify the `sdist` format as `gztar` in our `setup.cfg` file, [similar to how it's done here](https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/blob/master/setup.cfg#L19). This adds a dependency on `pep517 >= 0.5.0`.

To Do:

- [ ] Convert `setup.py` invocation to `pep517.build` invocation
- [ ] Add `pep517 >= 0.5.0` to `requirements-dev.txt`
- [ ] Add `gztar` option to `setup.cfg`

items.title: RRule next occurence computation

milestone.title: wontfix
milestone.description: Milestone to distinguish issues and PRS that are not going to be included for whatever reason from those that just haven't been assigned a milestone.

items.body:
# Summary

In some case, when I use the ``after`` method to compute the next occurrence of a rrule. The occurrence returned is not correct : 1 day is added to the expected occurrence start.

Did I do something wrong ?

## How to reproduce

```python
#!/bin/env python2.7

from dateutil import tz
from datetime import datetime
from dateutil.rrule import rrulestr

rrule = "FREQ=WEEKLY;BYDAY=FR"
rrule_start = 1536880500  # Thursday 13 September 2018 23:15:00 UTC

from_now = 1539846000  # Thursday 18 October 2018 07:00:00 UTC

dt_start = datetime.utcfromtimestamp(rrule_start).replace(tzinfo=tz.UTC)

dt_after = datetime.utcfromtimestamp(from_now).replace(tzinfo=tz.UTC)

occ = rrulestr(rrule, dtstart=dt_start).after(dt_after)
print("Rrule start {}.".format(dt_start))
print("First occurence after {} : {}.".format(dt_after, occ))
```
## Current behavior
For a rrule "FREQ=WEEKLY;BYDAY=FR" with a start date at Thursday 13 September 2018 23:15:00 UTC, when I compute the next occurrence after the Thursday 18 October 2018 07:00:00 UTC the next occurrence returned is 2018-10-19 23:15:00+00:00.

## Expected behavior
The ``after`` method should have returned an occurrence that start at 2018-10-19 23:15:00+00:00.

## Additional informations
 - dateutil : 2.7.3
 - python : 2.7.9

items.title: rrule with YEARLY frequency starting on a leap day

milestone.title: wontfix
milestone.description: Milestone to distinguish issues and PRS that are not going to be included for whatever reason from those that just haven't been assigned a milestone.

items.body:
Suppose I wanted to get when to celebrate birthdays with rrule. Then the frequency YEARLY works fine, except for leap days. There it is in fact only every 4 years.

Is there any way to deal with it directly with rrule?


    from datetime import datetime
    from dateutil.rrule import rrule, YEARLY

    n = 1
    print(list(rrule(freq=YEARLY, count=n + 1, dtstart=datetime(1990, 4, 28))))
    print(list(rrule(freq=YEARLY, count=n + 1, dtstart=datetime(1992, 2, 29))))

gives

    [datetime.datetime(1990, 4, 28, 0, 0), datetime.datetime(1991, 4, 28, 0, 0)]
    [datetime.datetime(1992, 2, 29, 0, 0), datetime.datetime(1996, 2, 29, 0, 0)]

The fact that leap days are not even mentioned [in the docs](https://dateutil.readthedocs.io/en/stable/rrule.html) makes me wonder if this might simply be a bug.

## byyearday

This might help, but only for the 28th of February:

    from datetime import datetime
    from dateutil.rrule import rrule, YEARLY

    n = 5

    bday = datetime(1990, 4, 28)
    print(list(rrule(freq=YEARLY,
                     byyearday=bday.timetuple().tm_yday,
                     count=n + 1,
                     dtstart=bday)))

    bday = datetime(1992, 2, 29)
    print(list(rrule(freq=YEARLY,
                     byyearday=bday.timetuple().tm_yday,
                     count=n + 1,
                     dtstart=bday)))

gives

    [datetime.datetime(1990, 4, 28, 0, 0), datetime.datetime(1991, 4, 28, 0, 0), datetime.datetime(1992, 4, 27, 0, 0), datetime.datetime(1993, 4, 28, 0, 0), datetime.datetime(1994, 4, 28, 0, 0), datetime.datetime(1995, 4, 28, 0, 0)]
    [datetime.datetime(1992, 2, 29, 0, 0), datetime.datetime(1993, 3, 1, 0, 0), datetime.datetime(1994, 3, 1, 0, 0), datetime.datetime(1995, 3, 1, 0, 0), datetime.datetime(1996, 2, 29, 0, 0), datetime.datetime(1997, 3, 1, 0, 0)]

items.title: Parser only partially accounts for case-insensitive nature of ISO8601 datestamps
items.body:
```bash
$ python -c "from dateutil.parser import parse
> print parse('1970-01-01T00:00:00Z')
> print parse('1970-01-01t00:00:00Z')
> print parse('1970-01-01t00:00:00')
> print parse('1970-01-01t00:00:00z')"
1970-01-01 00:00:00+00:00
1970-01-01 00:00:00+00:00
1970-01-01 00:00:00
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<string>", line 5, in <module>
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/dateutil/parser.py", line 1182, in parse
    return DEFAULTPARSER.parse(timestr, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/dateutil/parser.py", line 559, in parse
    raise ValueError("Unknown string format")
ValueError: Unknown string format
```

It looks like this library properly supports both the use of `t` and `T` as legal time separators for ISO8601 datestamps, but only supports the uppercased shorthand for UTC (`Z`), and not `z`. From what I can find online (namely, this RFC: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6), it seems like the latter is also legal syntax.

items.title: utcoffset/tzname incorrect immediately before Samoan offset change
items.body:
First reported by @MartinThoma in [this SO question](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/52136980), it seems that there is a bug in the way `tzfile` handles the local transition times during a base offset change:

```python
from datetime import datetime, timedelta
from dateutil import tz

APIA = tz.gettz('Pacific/Apia')
dt0 = datetime.fromisoformat('2011-12-29T20:00-10:00')

for i in range(5):
    dt = (dt0 + timedelta(hours=i))
    dt = dt.astimezone(APIA)
    print(f'{dt.isoformat()}')

## Result:
# 2011-12-29T20:00:00-10:00
# 2011-12-29T21:00:00-10:00
# 2011-12-29T22:00:00-10:00
# 2011-12-29T23:00:00+14:00
# 2011-12-31T00:00:00+14:00
```

Note that while `fromutc` sets the local datetime correctly, `utcoffset` returns `+14:00` an hour early! This is because the assumption in the code is that these base offset shifts don't happen during DST, which leads to the "local" (but not the UTC) transition time being off by 1 DST offset.

PR #810 should fix this.

items.title: tz.gettz broken when time zone not found
items.body:
When we switched over to using weak references for caching (see #635), we didn't take into account the fact that occasionally `tz.gettz` returns `None` (when no `tzinfo` object is found). Since you cannot have a weak reference to `None`, when we try to populate the weak cache, it raises an error.

This can be reproduced with:

```python
from dateutil import tz
tz.gettz('🐼')
```

The result:
> TypeError: cannot create weak reference to 'NoneType' object

This is causing failures in pandas' test suite: https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/issues/22337

items.title: Accept more than 6 digits for fractional seconds in isoparse
items.body:
Currently, `isoparse` raises an exception if there are more than 6 digits in the fractional second.

```
>>> dateutil.parser.isoparse("2006-01-02T15:04:05.9999999-07:00")
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/jay/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/dateutil/parser/isoparser.py", line 37, in func
    return f(self, str_in, *args, **kwargs)
  File "/home/jay/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/dateutil/parser/isoparser.py", line 136, in isoparse
    components += self._parse_isotime(dt_str[pos + 1:])
  File "/home/jay/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/dateutil/parser/isoparser.py", line 363, in _parse_isotime
    raise ValueError('Unused components in ISO string')
ValueError: Unused components in ISO string
```

Go, for example, includes up to 9 digits (nanosecond precision) when marshaling a time into JSON. It would be nice if `isoparse` could accept those without issue, even if precision gets truncated a bit.

items.title: Add 'sys.prefix/share/zoneinfo' to the beginning of tz/tz.TZPATH
items.body:
To support non-system prefix installation tree of software (e.g., `$HOME/.local`), it would be great if the search for the `zoneinfo` directory to be consulted first by the prefix where `sys.executable` first, followed by the remaining system default locations.

I don't see any tests related to the `TZPATH`.  Any recommendations for providing one?  Or are you comfortable with a patch to update the `TZPATH` list?

items.title: Fix parser link in documentation exercises
items.body: In the [documentation exercises](https://dateutil.readthedocs.io/en/latest/exercises/index.html#parsing-a-local-tzname), there is a link to "`dateutil.parse`" which should instead read "`dateutil.parser`". The link should be to `../parser.html` rather than `../parse.html`.

items.title: Add setup_requires to pyproject.toml
items.body: As part of [PEP 518](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0518/), build dependencies should now go into `pyproject.toml`. I think that only `pip>=10.0` supports this feature at the moment, so I don't think we can remove `setup_requires` entirely, but the two do not conflict, because `pip` will install all the setup requirements *before* invoking `setup.py`, which will thus find all its setup requirements already satisfied.

items.title: Add readme_renderer check to docs test
items.body:
Right now we don't do any automated testing that the README will be rendered correctly on PyPI. PyPI's long description renderer is very finicky and if there are any mistakes, it will fail to render *at all* and just be a bunch of ugly markup.

I think we can test this in the test suite by adding a [`readme_renderer`](https://pypi.org/project/readme_renderer/) check to the `docs` build for `tox`. So add `readme_renderer` to the `deps` for [`testenv:docs`](https://github.com/dateutil/dateutil/blob/master/tox.ini#L53), and then add to the commands `python setup.py -r -s`.

To test that it works, deliberately break the README in some way and make sure that `tox -e docs` fails.

items.title: Tests failing on Python 3.3
items.body:
The tests seem to be failing on Python 3.3 due to a wheel incompatibility.

My best guess for what is happening is that `wheel` dropped support for Python 3.3 and something in the testing pipeline (only seems to be happening on Travis as far as I can tell) is using an old version of `pip`.

My suspicion is that Travis has some code that creates a `virtualenv`, and it does so with an un-upgraded version of `pip`, which breaks on Python 3.3. It might be best to kick this over to Travis's github issues and see if we can get it fixed there. Otherwise we'll probably have to modify the way Travis creates its virtualenvs.

In the end we'll just drop Python 3.3 support soon enough, but I'd like to make sure I can do this in a pinch if need be and I don't like the idea of being forced to drop Python 3.3 by a misconfigured CI. Generally I don't drop support for a version of Python unless it's burdensome to continue supporting it in the code itself (i.e. a descriptive approach to version support). That hasn't happened for Python 3.3 yet.

items.title: setup.py has both requires and install_requires, leading to invalid metadata
items.body:
Both the deprecated `requires` and the current `install_requires` are used:

https://github.com/dateutil/dateutil/blob/ad9807375b0f524cb9cef38abac70cacee693d36/setup.py#L65-L67

This results in the following lines in the wheel's METADATA file:

```
Requires: six
Requires-Dist: six (>=1.5)
```

distlib rejects this file as having an inconsistent set of headers:

```
>>> from distlib.database import InstalledDistribution
>>> InstalledDistribution("python_dateutil-2.7.3.dist-info")
Attempting to set metadata for <LegacyMetadata python-dateutil 2.7.3>
Removed 1.0 due to Maintainer
Removed 1.1 due to Maintainer
Removed 1.2 due to Description-Content-Type
Removed 2.0 due to Description-Content-Type
Removed 1.3 due to Requires
Removed 2.1 due to Requires
Out of options - unknown metadata set: {u'Maintainer': u'Paul Ganssle', u'Name': u'python-dateutil', u'License': u'Dual License', u'Author': u'Gustavo Niemeyer', u'Requires-Python': u'>=2.7, !=3.0.*, !=3.1.*, !=3.2.*', u'Requires-Dist': [u'six (>=1.5)'], u'Maintainer-email': u'dateutil@python.org', u'Metadata-Version': u'2.1', u'Home-page': u'https://dateutil.readthedocs.io', u'Description-Content-Type': u'text/x-rst', u'Platform': [u'UNKNOWN'], u'Version': u'2.7.3', u'Summary': u'Extensions to the standard Python datetime module', u'Requires': [u'six'], u'Classifier': [u'Development Status :: 5 - Production/Stable', u'Intended Audience :: Developers', u'License :: OSI Approved :: BSD License', u'License :: OSI Approved :: Apache Software License', u'Programming Language :: Python', u'Programming Language :: Python :: 2', u'Programming Language :: Python :: 2.7', u'Programming Language :: Python :: 3', u'Programming Language :: Python :: 3.3', u'Programming Language :: Python :: 3.4', u'Programming Language :: Python :: 3.5', u'Programming Language :: Python :: 3.6', u'Programming Language :: Python :: 3.7', u'Topic :: Software Development :: Libraries'], u'Author-email': u'gustavo@niemeyer.net'}
Traceback (most recent call last):
[...]
  File "/home/smith/.virtualenvs/pypi/lib/python3.6/site-packages/distlib/database.py", line 555, in __init__
    metadata = Metadata(fileobj=stream, scheme='legacy')
  File "/home/smith/.virtualenvs/pypi/lib/python3.6/site-packages/distlib/metadata.py", line 737, in __init__
    scheme=scheme)
  File "/home/smith/.virtualenvs/pypi/lib/python3.6/site-packages/distlib/metadata.py", line 281, in __init__
    self.read_file(fileobj)
  File "/home/smith/.virtualenvs/pypi/lib/python3.6/site-packages/distlib/metadata.py", line 381, in read_file
    self.set_metadata_version()
  File "/home/smith/.virtualenvs/pypi/lib/python3.6/site-packages/distlib/metadata.py", line 287, in set_metadata_version
    self._fields['Metadata-Version'] = _best_version(self._fields)
  File "/home/smith/.virtualenvs/pypi/lib/python3.6/site-packages/distlib/metadata.py", line 165, in _best_version
    raise MetadataConflictError('Unknown metadata set')
distlib.metadata.MetadataConflictError: Unknown metadata set
```

This didn't happen with previous versions of dateutil, because they contained a metadata.json, which distlib prefers and parses in a different way. But the recent dateutil version 2.7.3 doesn't contain the metadata.json.

ALthough distlib is distributed as a standalone package for use with tools like mine, it exists primarily as a component of pip. pip itself isn't currently affected by this problem, because it parses the METADATA file using `pkg_resources` instead. However, I wouldn't be surprised if that changed in the future, in which case new versions of pip would be unable to install this version of dateutil.

Anyway, the solution is to remove the "requires" line. It's been deprecated since PEP 345, 13 years ago, and as far as I can tell, pip completely ignores it.

items.title: [Feature Request] Adding the ability to disable automatic century detection

milestone.title: wontfix
milestone.description: Milestone to distinguish issues and PRS that are not going to be included for whatever reason from those that just haven't been assigned a milestone.

items.body:
Currently `dateutil` would try converting two-digit years, and [here](http://labix.org/python-dateutil/#head-19e5d3331806e55ec2ba1b9e39458784cc0a0004) is the corresponding section in the doc describing its behavior.

While it's generally helpful, there're still specific cases where it's a pain. E.g. a user may want all two-digit year values to be regarded as in the 1900s.

Currently it's possible to disable automatic century detection by sub-classing the `dateutil.parser.parserinfo` class, or via a patch like this:
```
>>> import dateutil.parser
>>> dateutil.parser.parse('65-12-01')
datetime.datetime(2065, 12, 1, 0, 0)
>>> old_init = dateutil.parser._parser._ymd.__init__
>>> def new_init(self, *args, **kwargs):
...   old_init(self, *args, **kwargs)
...   self.century_specified = True
... 
>>> dateutil.parser._parser._ymd.__init__ = new_init
>>> dateutil.parser.parse('65-12-01')
datetime.datetime(65, 12, 1, 0, 0)
```

I suppose it might be a good idea to include the feature as an optional argument of `dateutil.parser.parse`.

The pgp.mit.edu keyserver has been having a lot of 503 errors lately, which has been causing the `tox -e docs` builds to fail their dead links check.

It might be a good idea to switch that over to a new endpoint that is more stable, or add a mirror.

I'm also thinking that maybe the link error checker might need to be an "allowed-fail" on PRs. It's super useful in preventing linkrot, but it's causing a lot of false alarm Travis build failures.

items.title: Add LRU cache to gettz and factories
items.body:
Now that #635 is resolved, `gettz`, `tzoffset` and `tzstr` satisfies the property that two `tzinfo` objects (`tz1` and `tz2`) constructed with identical arguments will always be the same object (`tz1` is `tz2`), but the cached objects expire whenever no instances of a given timezone exist outside of the cache. This satisfies the "timezone semantics" reasons for adding a cache and will have good performance characteristics so long as at least one object holds a strong reference to the time zone.

But this *does* sacrifice performance for people who would prefer a cache because they are creating the same object over and over again even though it goes out of scope every time, so for example:

```python
def NY_timestamp(dt):
    dt.astimezone(tz.gettz('America/New_York')
    return dt.timestamp()

a = []
for i in range(10000):
    a.append(NY_timestamp(datetime.now()))
```

I think the above would needlessly create 10000 copies of `tz.gettz('America/New_York')`, when even a modest LRU cache would save the trouble.

I think we should leave the `_instances` dictionary as a `WeakValueDictionary` and add a second `_lru_cache` dictionary that holds a limited (and configurable) number of strong references to used time zones. Not sure the best implementation of the cache itself, preferably something where left-append, right-pop and reordering a single element are all O(1), so I think something implemented with a doubly-linked list (maybe `OrderedDict`).

Presumably we can take some cues from the implementation of [`functools.lru_cache`](https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/master/Lib/functools.py#L445), but keep in mind that the Python implementation may not have amazing performance, since CPython has a C implementation and may not have spent much time optimizing the Python implementation.

items.title: Parser error with unambiguous date in year 31

milestone.description: Bugfix release.

items.body:
I started converting [this test](https://github.com/dateutil/dateutil/blob/master/dateutil/test/test_parser.py#L33) over to a hypothesis-based property test and found the following failure:

```python
from dateutil.parser import parse
from datetime import datetime

dt = datetime(31, 12, 30)
dstr = dt.strftime('%B.%04Y.%d')    # December.0031.30
parse(dt.strftime('%B.%04Y.%d'))     # datetime(30, 12, 31, 0, 0)
```

Pretty low priority, but related to #293. Here's the full hypothesis test that generates these examples:

```python
from datetime import datetime, time
import itertools

from hypothesis.strategies import integers, dates
from hypothesis import given

import pytest

from dateutil.parser import parserinfo, parse


def _get_ybd_formats():
    # If we have a 4-digit year, a non-numeric month (abbreviated or not),
    # and a day (1 or 2 digits), then there is no ambiguity as to which
    # token is a year/month/day.  This holds regardless of what order the
    # terms are in and for each of the separators below.
    try:
        datetime.now().strftime('%-d')
        PLATFORM_HAS_DASH_D = True
    except ValueError:
        PLATFORM_HAS_DASH_D = False

    seps = ['-', ' ', '/', '.']

    year_tokens = ['%04Y']
    month_tokens = ['%b', '%B']
    day_tokens = ['%d']

    if PLATFORM_HAS_DASH_D:
        day_tokens.append('%-d')

    prods = itertools.product(year_tokens, month_tokens, day_tokens)
    perms = [y for x in prods for y in itertools.permutations(x)]
    unambig_fmts = [sep.join(perm) for sep in seps for perm in perms]

    return unambig_fmts


@pytest.mark.parser
@pytest.mark.parametrize('fmt', _get_ybd_formats())
@given(dt=dates())
def test_ybd(dt, fmt):
    dt = datetime.combine(dt, time(0))  # Make this a datetime
    dstr = dt.strftime(fmt)
    res = parse(dstr)
    assert dt == res
```

In the end we may also want to change `_get_ybd_formats` over to a strategy, because I think repeating dozens of hypothesis tests separately is expensive.

items.title: Ordering in the rrule documentation keywords explanation
items.body:
There is a difference in the order in which the arguments are listed in the function definition(at the beginning of the documentation), and the order in which they are explained. Specifically, cache is the last argument given when we are defining the function in the documentation, but is the first one to be explained.  (http://dateutil.readthedocs.io/en/stable/rrule.html). Another out-of-order keyword is byeaster.

Should we change the ordering in http://dateutil.readthedocs.io/en/stable/_modules/dateutil/rrule.html#rrule to make it consistent?

The issue is [this line](https://github.com/dateutil/dateutil/blame/master/docs/relativedelta.rst#L143), which currently reads:

items.title: Exercise: Martin Luther King day

milestone.title: Master
milestone.description: This is a general milestone for things that are useful between releases, like build and test improvements.

items.body:
This is an example exercise to be solved by a new user to the library *using only the dateutil documentation*, per #663.

# Exercise: Martin Luther King, Jr Day
> [Martin Luther King, Jr Day](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr._Day) is a US holiday that occurs every year on the third Monday in January.
>
> How would you generate a [recurrence rule](https://dateutil.readthedocs.io/en/latest/rrule.html) that generates Martin Luther King Day, starting from the first observance of the holiday in 1986?

### Test cases:
```python
from datetime import datetime

MLK_TEST_CASES = [
    ((datetime(1970, 1, 1), datetime(1980, 1, 1)),
     []),
    ((datetime(1980, 1, 1), datetime(1989, 1, 1)),
     [datetime(1986, 1, 20),
      datetime(1987, 1, 19),
      datetime(1988, 1, 18)]),
    ((datetime(2017, 2, 1), datetime(2022, 2, 1)),
     [datetime(2018, 1, 15, 0, 0),
      datetime(2019, 1, 21, 0, 0),
      datetime(2020, 1, 20, 0, 0),
      datetime(2021, 1, 18, 0, 0),
      datetime(2022, 1, 17, 0, 0)]
     ),
]


def test_mlk_day(rr):
    for (between_args, expected) in MLK_TEST_CASES:
        assert rr.between(*between_args) == expected
```

To Do:

- [x] Add this exercise to the documentation
- [ ] Add solution to the documentation
- [x] Improve documentation for `rrule` based on this

items.title: Documentation exercises

milestone.title: Master
milestone.description: This is a general milestone for things that are useful between releases, like build and test improvements.

items.body:
This is a new kind of "issue" I'd like to try out that is *specifically* for people new to the library.

I will propose a problem that I know can be solved using `dateutil`, and I'd like one or more users to try to solve this puzzle using *only* the [`dateutil` documentation](https://dateutil.readthedocs.io/en/latest/).

We'll put these examples as "exercises" in the documentation, possibly with solutions on a different page. The idea is that new users will try these exercises and use their experience to improve the documentation - if the documentation alone doesn't adequately explain how to solve the problem, it needs to be improved!

Since the whole idea of this is that the documentation is *probably* inadequate, people can ask for guidance in the [gitter](https://gitter.im/dateutil/dateutil) or in person at sprints when they get stuck (or they can look at the code, but always write down what they had to "peek" for!

items.title: Allow tzinfos to return None

milestone.description: Bugfix release.

items.body:
Currently, if you the result of a `tzinfos` call *explicitly* returns `None`, that will throw an error:

```python
>>> from dateutil.parser import parse
>>> parse('2017-02-03 12:40 MGX', tzinfos={'MGX': None})
...
ValueError: Offset must be tzinfo subclass, tz string, or int offset.
>>> parse('2017-02-03 12:40 RDT', tzinfos={'XXX': None})
[...] UnknownTimezoneWarning: tzname RDT identified but not understood.  Pass `tzinfos`
argument in order to correctly return a timezone-aware datetime.  In a future version,
this raise an exception.
  category=UnknownTimezoneWarning)
datetime.datetime(2014, 2, 3, 2, 3)
```

The whole point of #540  was that implicitly silently failing was a bad behavior, but you should certainly be able to opt in to not caring about the time zone by returning `None`.

Note: As an aside, there's a typo I didn't notice there, it says "In a future version, this raise an exception", should be "this *will* raise an exception."

items.title: relativedelta division

milestone.title: wontfix
milestone.description: Milestone to distinguish issues and PRS that are not going to be included for whatever reason from those that just haven't been assigned a milestone.

items.body:
In `datetime`, it is possible to divide two `timedelta`s:

```python
import datetime
print(datetime.timedelta(1) / datetime.timedelta(2))  # output: 05
```

However the same is not possible in `dateutil` with `relativedelta`:

```python
import dateutil.relativedelta
dateutil.relativedelta.relativedelta(days=1) / dateutil.relativedelta.relativedelta(days=2)
# TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for /: 'relativedelta' and 'relativedelta'
```

I feel it would be good to include this functionality in `dateutil`. I know it would not make sense in some cases but I feel in many it would. Thoughts?
